722274f-a.text:
Park Avenue, south from 55th Street, where the railroad emerges from the tunnel and the Grand Central Yards begin. The Avenue will be built over the tracks to 52nd Street by 1910. On west side, note houses between 54th and 53rd Street, which will still be standing thirty years later. On the west side, note old Steinway Piano Factory, dating back to the Civil War or earlier, which will be demolished in 1911. Beyond it may be seen the tower of F&M Shaefer's brewery, about the same age on the S.E. corner of 51st Street where the new St. Bartholomew's Church will be built in 1918. Compare with Edison Company's photo of the same scene in 1927. June 10, 1905.

New York's Edison Company Collection.

722245f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east side, from 51st to 52nd Street. Part of the old F&M Schaefer Brewery, about to be demolished in the block where the Ambassador Hotel is to be built. In the block below, which has been purchased By St. Bartholomew's church, the main part of the old brewery has already been demolished. 1917.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

713514f-a.text:
121 East 5lth Street, northside between Park and Lexingon Avenues showing P.S. 18. 1920.

Board of Education, N.Y.C.

722239f.text:
Park Avenue, north from 51st Street, about 9:30 A.M., showing buildings along east side. It is possible to see nearly a mile of the Avenue. Notice Hotel Ambassador, 51st to 52d Streets, built in 1919 and the Montane Apartments (1912) between 52nd and 53rd Streets. The tiny building on the N.E. corner of 53rd Street is a survival of the era before the railroad was electrified, about 1924 it will be demolished. No. 441, in the N.E. corner of 56th Street, also dates back to the 1880's. Note cross-town street-cars at 59th Street. 1921.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

713517f-a.text:
5lst Street west from east of Park Avenue.
April 8, 1928.
P.L. Sperr.

722267f-a.text:
Park Ave., at the S.E. corner of East 54th Street. July 11, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

722238f-a.text:
Park Avenue, north from and including 51st Street, showing buildings along the west side, also the parks in the center, shaved to make room for more traffic.

The five story building between 52nd and 53rd Street is the Racquet and Tennis Club, and behind it on the horizon rises the Tower of the Fuller Building at Madison Ave and 57th St.

The small buildings in the block above, 53rd to 54th St, are much older then their surroundings, dating back to at least 1890s.

On the east side, just north of St. Bartholomew's, is the Hotel Ambassador.

Summer 1929

713515f-a.text:
5lst Street, north side, between Lexington and Park Avenues, with Public School No. 18 in the centre, and the Hotel Ambassador on
the left.
May 3, 1930.
P.L. Sperr.

722244f-a.text:
Hotel Ambassador (built 1918-19), Park Avenue, east side, from 51st to 52nd Streets. Campare this photograph with the same scene
in 1917. About 1932.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

722247f-a.text:
A general view of the Grand Central 2one as viewed southward on Park Ave. from East 52nd Street, at which point appears the Hotel Ambassador (left foreground) with St. Bartholomew's P.E. Church just beyond (S.E. corner of 51et Street). Prominently shown (centre) is the new Waldorf Astoria Hotel flanked on one side by the R.C.A. Building and the Chrysler, Chanin, Grand Central Palace and Lincoln Buildings on the other. Distinctly shown between the R.C.A. Building and the Waldorf Astoria Hotel is Tudor City located near the East River, which is dimly apparent on the left.
October 31, 1932.

Wurts Brothers.

Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer

51st Street, south side, from Park to Madison Avenues.
May 15, 1933.
